_comment: This file is generated. Please edit .homeycompose/app.json instead.

description.en: Adds support for deCONZ's [raspbee/conbee] child devices

title.en: A device has become reachable (after it was unreachable)
Remote has been rotated counter clockwise
title.nl: Afstandsbediening tegen de klok in gedraaid
Afstandsbediening met de klok mee gedraaid

hint.en: Important: in the device settings you can set the mode of this switch. This setting defines what buttons are available and what events are supported. Keep this in mind when using this flow card as not all buttons/events might be supported depending on your settings!

This device sends a lot of events which is not very performant if you need to react on everyone of them. Instead throttling is used which only triggers this card once every second but then provides and 'event count' that tell you how many emits were omitted. You can use this to derive how much or how fast the rotation was. Note that you can adapt this behaviour in the device settings.

title.en: Remote has been sharply rotated counter clockwise
title.nl: Afstandsbediening tegen de klok in gedraaid

title.en: Remote has been sharply rotated clockwise
title.nl: Afstandsbediening met de klok mee gedraaid

title.en: DeConz Docker image update is available
When the tilt alarm is !{{|not}} detected

titleFormatted.en: When the vibration strength is !{{greater|lower}} than [[value]]
When the tilt angle is !{{greater|lower}} than [[value]]

title.en: When the relative tilt angle is !{{greater|lower}}

titleFormatted.en: When the relative tilt angle is !{{greater|lower}} than [[value]]

hint.en: The backup gets stored on your Homey. Please visit the app config -> advanced to get more details or download the stored backup file.
Simulates an incoming websocket message. This can be useful for a few tests. Only use this if you know what you're doing.
Apply one or more light commands that all will be applied natively which will get you a smoother expirience than doing so with separate commands.

titleFormatted.en: Set combined state: power: [[power]], brightness: [[brightness_mode]]->([[brightness]]/[[relative_increasement_brightness]]), saturation: [[saturation_mode]] -> ([[saturation]]/[[relative_increasement_saturation]]), hue: [[hue_mode]] -> ([[hue]]/[[relative_increasement_hue]]), color temperature: [[ct_mode]] -> ([[ct]]/[[relative_increasement_ct]]), color mode: [[colormode]] within [[transitiontime]]

hint.en: applies only if the brightness mode is set to 'absolute'
applies only if the brightness mode is set to 'relative'
applies only if the saturation mode is set to 'absolute'
applies only if the saturation mode is set to 'relative'
applies only if the hue mode is set to 'absolute'
applies only if the hue mode is set to 'relative'
applies only if the color temperature mode is set to 'absolute'
applies only if the color temperature mode is set to 'relative'
Apply one or more light commands that all will be applied natively which will get you a smoother expirience than doing so with separate commands.

titleFormatted.en: Set combined state: power: [[power]], brightness: [[brightness_mode]]->([[brightness]]/[[relative_increasement_brightness]]), saturation: [[saturation_mode]] -> ([[saturation]]/[[relative_increasement_saturation]]), hue: [[hue_mode]] -> ([[hue]]/[[relative_increasement_hue]]), color temperature: [[ct_mode]] -> ([[ct]]/[[relative_increasement_ct]]), color mode: [[colormode]] within [[transitiontime]]

hint.en: applies only if the brightness mode is set to 'absolute'
applies only if the brightness mode is set to 'relative'
applies only if the saturation mode is set to 'absolute'
applies only if the saturation mode is set to 'relative'
applies only if the hue mode is set to 'absolute'
applies only if the hue mode is set to 'relative'
applies only if the color temperature mode is set to 'absolute'
applies only if the color temperature mode is set to 'relative'

titleFormatted.en: Set the relative brightness to [[relative_brightness]] within [[transitiontime]]
Set the relative color temperature to [[relative_ct]] within [[transitiontime]]

placeholder.en: Effect Speed (supported by some effects only)
Effect Color 1 (supported by some effects only)
Effect Color 2 (supported by some effects only)
Effect Color 3 (supported by some effects only)
Effect Color 4 (supported by some effects only)
Effect Color 5 (supported by some effects only)
Effect Color 6 (supported by some effects only)

hint.en: In Zigbee networks there are no active connections and thus deCONZ does not know if this device is still there as long as it does not communicate. Therefore a device gets marked as unreachable if it does not report for a longer period of time. This is perfectly fine for most devices as they report their status periodically, but if this devices doesn't do this, you can prevent that it get's reported as unavailable using this setting.

In Zigbee networks there are no active connections and thus deCONZ does not know if this device is still there as long as it does not communicate. Therefore a device gets marked as unreachable if it does not report for a longer period of time. This is perfectly fine for most devices as they report their status periodically, but if this devices doesn't do this, you can prevent that it get's reported as unavailable using this setting.

This setting will translate the actual measured rotation angle in a relative rotation angle that can be used to increase or decrease dim-level / volume.
xx¬∞ = 100%
Range: 90 - 360, 
default: 180 [¬∞]

In Zigbee networks there are no active connections and thus deCONZ does not know if this device is still there as long as it does not communicate. Therefore a device gets marked as unreachable if it does not report for a longer period of time. This is perfectly fine for most devices as they report their status periodically, but if this devices doesn't do this, you can prevent that it get's reported as unavailable using this setting.
By default the alarm will be triggered when the door/window get's detected as open. Using this setting you can invert this which enables a few interesting use cases

In Zigbee networks there are no active connections and thus deCONZ does not know if this device is still there as long as it does not communicate. Therefore a device gets marked as unreachable if it does not report for a longer period of time. This is perfectly fine for most devices as they report their status periodically, but if this devices doesn't do this, you can prevent that it get's reported as unavailable using this setting.
The sensor reports when there is no more motion detected. Using this setting you can increase the time (in seconds) until the motion alarm gets disabled.
Triggers an secondary no motion event after the motion alarm has been disabled. Usefull to generate Philips Hue like behaviour easily.

If a sensor is not properly calibrated it will read slightly wrong values. Using this setting you can adjust the sensor readings, i.e if you set a value of -2.5 and the sensor reports 20, the sensor will show a value of 17.5 within Homey.

Time after which the tilt alarm gets disabled after it has been triggered
Note that the sensitivity gets applied the next time the sensor performs a handshake with the conbee. This might take up to some time! Hint: 0 = most sensitive and 21 = least sensitive!
Hardware settings that are not yet applied to the sensor.

Transition time between brightnesses in 100ms steps (ex: a value of 4 means 400ms, a value of 10 would be 1 second).

There are two different options available to control the color of a light. By default hs (hue amd saturation) is used. Using this setting you can use xy (CIELAB) instead. Only use this if you know what you're doing!

In Zigbee networks there are no active connections and thus deCONZ does not know if this device is still there as long as it does not communicate. Therefore a device gets marked as unreachable if it does not report for a longer period of time. This is perfectly fine for most devices as they report their status periodically, but if this devices doesn't do this, you can prevent that it get's reported as unavailable using this setting.
Transition time between brightnesses in 100ms steps (ex: a value of 4 means 400ms, a value of 10 would be 1 second).

There are two different options available to control the color of a light. By default hs (hue amd saturation) is used. Using this setting you can use xy (CIELAB) instead. Only use this if you know what you're doing!

If a sensor is not properly calibrated it will read slightly wrong values. Using this setting you can adjust the sensor readings, i.e if you set a value of -2.5 and the sensor reports 20, the sensor will show a value of 17.5 within Homey.

If a sensor is not properly calibrated it will read slightly wrong values. Using this setting you can adjust the sensor readings, i.e if you set a value of -2.5 and the sensor reports 20, the sensor will show a value of 17.5 within Homey.

The sensor reports when there is no more motion detected. Using this setting you can increase the time (in seconds) until the motion alarm gets disabled.
Triggers an secondary no motion event after the motion alarm has been disabled. Usefull to generate Philips Hue like behaviour easily.

In Zigbee networks there are no active connections and thus deCONZ does not know if this device is still there as long as it does not communicate. Therefore a device gets marked as unreachable if it does not report for a longer period of time. This is perfectly fine for most devices as they report their status periodically, but if this devices doesn't do this, you can prevent that it get's reported as unavailable using this setting.
By default the alarm will be triggered when the door/window get's detected as open. Using this setting you can invert this which enables a few interesting use cases

This device sends a lot of rotation events which is not reasonable to be used in flows. Instead, this setting defines the interval in which rotation events are emitted. The amount of events that have been skipped is noted as the 'event count' token

The amount of emited rotation events can be used as indicator for the relative rotation. Use this scale parameter to get an appropriate 'relative rotation' for you use case. Example: Let's assume a normal rotation of 90¬∞ takes one second and emits 4 events and you wan't this to be the equivalent of 0.5 for dimming a light to 50% so you would set the scaling to 0.128.
